ladyginamaree: I love how you are open and free about being queer and still committed to your partner. You inspire me. I love your spirit. ❤❤❤Thank you for being so open!
rae_virginia: I was feeling sad about being demi today. Thank you for sharing this. I really needed the encouragement and to know I'm not alone and to see brave queer black femmes like you. It's still hard because there's so much pressure to be "accessible" especially in queer spaces and being introverted and demi is hard. It's hard to feel like I am enough. I have struggled a lot with feeling like I need to prove that I'm not a prude or whatever other stereotypes and misconceptions people have about demi people. But I am trying to believe that I am enough. And my queerness isn't defined by how many partners I have or how uninhibited I am. 💙😔
wonderlass: I relate to so much of what you said that I feel like you read my mind and wrote out my thoughts. 😂

alyshalight: @evyan.whitney I’ve followed you since your Apricot Tea days & have watched your wonderful evolution. Curious to know if your non-monogamous status means you can (and do) take male & female partners? Curious bc it seems a lot of bi/queer women who are in open relationships with men all seem to take female partners only...& I’ve wondered if that’s just a coincidence or if their male partners just aren’t comfortable with them being with other men? Like, how does your man actually react after you’ve just had sex with someone else? I’d love to hear more about how a non-monogamous dynamic works when a bi woman is exercising that freedom with all genders. Also are there ever racial politics invoked?
